author: By Andrew Keh
title: Gregg Berhalter Rehired as U.S. Men’s Coach
description: Berhalter was removed from the post after the World Cup, but the results of an investigation cleared the way for his return.
content: The United States men’s soccer team announced Friday that it was rehiring Gregg Berhalter as its head coach for the run-up to the 2026 World Cup, concluding a monthslong, worldwide coaching search with the same man who had led the team from 2019 to 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Donald Trump Has a Polling Problem
description: Most Republicans still support Trump. But the polls still suggest the federal indictment is hurting him.
content: The 50 percent threshold in a poll can sometimes be distracting. When more than half of people give a certain answer, it often becomes the dominant message to emerge from the poll question. It is the answer that appears to have won. Yet the most important information may nonetheless be lurking elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: African Leaders Talk Peace in Ukraine, as Missiles Explode Overhead
description: After meeting with the Africans, including some who have close ties to Moscow, President Volodymyr Zelensky suggested that their peace plans were unrealistic.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and African leaders on a peace mission to Kyiv had testy exchanges on Friday on how to end the war with Russia, hours after Russian forces fired missiles at the capital while the African heads of government were there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Leigh Brown
title: There’s No Uber or Lyft. There Is a Communal Tesla.
description: An innovative E.V. ride-sharing program is bringing low-cost clean transportation to an agricultural town in California’s Central Valley. Others are following suit.
content: Three mornings a week, Herminia Ibarra makes her way to a fleet of sparkling electric vehicles lined up in a dusty alley alongside a former diesel repair shop. Of the five Chevy Bolts, three Tesla Ys, two Volkswagen e-Golfs and a BMW i3, she always tries to snag her favorite: the red Bolt set up with her Bluetooth. In this E.V., she will pick up the two retired farmworkers who are her regular clients and ferry them on two-lane roads to their dialysis appointments 20 miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Adam Satariano and Natasha Singer
title: Meta to Lower Age for Users of Virtual Reality Headset to 10 From 13
description: The company has reached out to regulators about its plans, which could set off privacy and safety concerns for parents and watchdogs.
content: Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, plans to lower the recommended age for using its Quest headset to 10 from 13, the company said in a blog post on Friday, a move that could set off new privacy and safety concerns with parents and global watchdogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
title: ‘I Cannot Believe We Made It’: In the Flood, a Rescue Behind the Front
description: To many, the destruction of a dam on the Dnipro River in Ukraine brought devastation. To some stranded in Russian-occupied territory, it brought freedom.
content: At night, she had looked at the twinkling lights of her home city, just a mile or so away but a world apart. For months, she had been kept away by the dangers of Russia’s war in Ukraine, stranded on a river island, after the front line shifted while she was on vacation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: After an Epic Meltdown, Ample Hills Creamery Aims to Rise Again
description: The Brooklyn-based ice cream chain boomed with the help of Oprah and Disney, then went bust. But the couple behind it are opening new shops and thinking small.
content: It was a sad day in Brooklyn when Ample Hills Creamery closed its doors. Just before last Christmas, the beloved ice cream parlor in Prospect Heights — and all 12 of its remaining scoop shops across the country — shut down after a decade-long roller-coaster ride of brand-building, bankruptcies and heartbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Miller
title: States Try Easing the Burden of Long-Term Care’s High Cost
description: Seeing their own financial benefits, too, Washington and California are among the states creating programs to help older residents.
content: It’s a retirement concern few of us want to face: At some point, four out of five older Americans will need help with daily needs like bathing, dressing, using the toilet or preparing meals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Who Says a Walk Can’t Be a Workout?
description: There are simple ways to increase intensity without turning your stroll into a slog.
content: We’re halfway through our monthlong newsletter series dedicated to the joys of walking. This week, we’re making our walk into a workout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Niki Kitsantonis
title: Hundreds Dead, 9 Arrested, and Many Questions in Migrant Wreck
description: Greek authorities blamed smugglers for a disaster that may have been one of the worst of its kind. Critics say tougher policies are increasing the risks.
content: At the end of a long stretch of sandy beach, a weathered warehouse in the Greek port of Kalamata held the survivors of one of the worst shipwrecks in Europe in a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Max Homa Takes His Star Turn at the U.S. Open
description: The California native had previously played well at Los Angeles Country Club, but first rounds at major tournaments haven’t always gone smoothly. On Thursday, he found his game for a two-under 68.
content: For a decade now, Max Homa has had regrets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: A Report Called for an Overhaul of Minneapolis Police
description: Also, a guilty verdict for the Pittsburgh synagogue gunman. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: George Floyd died more than three years ago at the hands of police officers in Minneapolis, igniting nationwide protests against discriminatory policing and spurring a federal investigation into the city’s police force. Today, the Justice Department released its findings in a scathing 89-page report that found systemic abuses by the police in Minneapolis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What It’s Like to Write an MLK Jr. Biography
description: Jonathan Eig discusses his new book about the life and times of Martin Luther King.
content: Jonathan Eig’s book “King: A Life” is the first comprehensive biography in decades of Martin Luther King Jr., drawing on reams of interviews and newly uncovered archival materials to paint a fuller picture of the civil rights leader than we have received before. “This is a very human, and quite humane, portrait,” our critic Dwight Garner wrote in his review. “Eig’s book is worthy of its subject.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: U.S. Open Shows a Fiercer Side, but Low Scores Abound Anyway
description: Brooks Koepka dreads a “birdiefest” at a major. But Los Angeles Country Club is giving the Open field only so much heartburn.
content: Few golfers relish a U.S. Open quite like Brooks Koepka. One at the Olympic Club was his first major tournament appearance. An iteration at Pinehurst saw his debut top-five finish in a major. He first lifted a major trophy at Erin Hills in 2017, and then he did it again the next year at Shinnecock Hills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich
title: 3 Men Charged in Case That Spotlights Attacks on the Media
description: The homes of New Hampshire Public Radio journalists were vandalized after they aired a sexual harassment investigation involving a prominent businessman in the state.
content: Federal prosecutors in Boston unveiled criminal charges on Friday against three men accused of vandalizing the homes of journalists in New Hampshire and Massachusetts in retaliation for an investigation into a local businessman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Creeping Shariah Has Nothing on the Woke Mob
description: How conservatives went from demonizing Muslims to wooing them.
content: In his speech at the Republican convention in 2016, Donald Trump spoke of the mass shooting at a gay nightclub in Orlando, where a man with jihadist sympathies murdered 49 people. “As your president, I will do everything in my power to protect our L.G.B.T.Q. citizens from the violence and oppression of a hateful foreign ideology,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Market Rally Intensifies Debate Over What Will Come Next
description: The stock market is on its longest winning streak since 2021. Some investors see trouble ahead.
content: The stock market is on a tear, and investors face a tricky question: Will the rally last?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Sapna Maheshwari
title: The Titanic Truthers of TikTok
description: On the short-form video app, long-established facts about the 1912 disaster at sea are being newly litigated as musty rumors merge with fresh misinformation and manipulated content.
content: The finer details of what happened to the RMS Titanic differ depending on who is telling the story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: How ‘Defund the Police’ Failed
description: In Minneapolis and elsewhere, the movement faltered after crime surged and activists failed to build broad support for a goal that lacked a clear definition.
content: More than three years after the murder of George Floyd focused the nation’s attention on racism in law enforcement, Minneapolis’s Third Precinct police station, which was set ablaze and looted during the tumultuous days after Mr. Floyd’s death, remains abandoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Murder in a Moneyed Fire Island Enclave
description: Gossips, cheaters and hypocrites strut through Emma Rosenblum’s delicious thriller of manners, “Bad Summer People.”
content: Who is the worst of the BAD SUMMER PEOPLE (Flatiron, 261 pp., $28.99) in Emma Rosenblum’s addictive thriller of manners set among the rich and socially anxious in Salcombe, a snooty village on New York’s Fire Island?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: ‘The Power of Trees:’ Among the ‘Machines’ Fighting Climate Change
description: Adrian Benepe of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden believes in trees and is highlighting them in a new exhibit. And New York’s City Council is back on the ballot starting Saturday.
content: Good morning. We’ll meet the Lorax of Brooklyn, who says trees in New York lessen the effects of climate change. Also, early voting for the June 27 primaries begins on Saturday, with ranked-choice voting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: The Rev. C. Welton Gaddy, Defender of Church-State Divide, Dies at 81
description: He started out in the Southern Baptist Convention, but when that group took a sharp conservative turn he became a voice for tolerance and diversity.
content: The Rev. C. Welton Gaddy, who started his career in the Southern Baptist Convention but became increasingly troubled as the denomination grew more aggressively conservative, and who went on to lead the Interfaith Alliance, an organization devoted to religious and cultural diversity and to keeping religion and politics separate, died on June 7 in Monroe, La. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Husband Is in His 70s and Won’t Retire. Can I Make Him?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what is reasonable to expect from a career-oriented partner.
content: I have been married for 50 years and dearly love my husband. We raised two children together and have always worked full time. I retired six months ago in the hope that my husband would leave his job as well. He is a hard worker who has been working remotely since March 2020. His job is both unpredictable and transactional. The chief executive of his company places unreasonable demands on him and his time and calls him even when we are on vacation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: An Investigation Into the Minneapolis Police, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: For Two Circus Performers, Love Takes Flight on and Off the Ground
description: A shared passion for acrobatics, costumes and bicycles led Ryan Murray and Juanita Cardenas to a wedding ceremony held in midair.
content: For circus performers, it takes a lot to stand out at a festival. But when Ryan Shinji Murray heard about how Juanita Cardenas arrived at the Montreal Complètement Cirque festival in 2015, he was intrigued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Frazer
title: How My Father and I Drew a New Life
description: After my mother died, my father had a choice: Give up or reinvent himself.
content: When I was 13, my mother learned that she had multiple sclerosis. By that point she couldn’t drive, get dressed or walk by herself. My father became her sole caretaker, and she was less than appreciative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: The Final Fight for Black Sailors Known as the ‘Philadelphia 15’
description: Kicked out of the Navy in 1940 for publicly criticizing the racist abuse they suffered on their warship, 15 Black men were posthumously exonerated at the Pentagon on Friday.
content: Just over a year before the attack on Pearl Harbor, 15 sailors assigned to the U.S.S. Philadelphia wrote a letter to a Black newspaper detailing the abuse and indignities they had faced on the warship solely because of the color of their skin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Biden Says He Plans to Appoint Mandy Cohen as C.D.C. Director
description: Dr. Cohen will replace Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky, an infectious disease expert who has overseen the agency since the beginning of Mr. Biden’s term and started a broad effort to reorganize it.
content: President Biden on Friday said that he planned to appoint Dr. Mandy Cohen, the former North Carolina health secretary, as the next director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a widely expected move that marks a major transition at the federal agency tasked with overseeing the nation’s public health infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jon Favreau
description: The June 16, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jon Favreau. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: A ‘Priest’ Walked Into a Taqueria. Investigators Say It Was Intimidation.
description: A Sacramento restaurant that was under investigation for wage theft brought in a man who claimed to be a priest to hear confession. Employees said he asked almost exclusively about work.
content: An owner of a Northern California taqueria was the target of a federal wage theft investigation in November 2021 when he brought in a strange guest to talk to his employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Core Inflation Has Gone Rotten
description: It’s a misleading relic of a bygone age.
content: This has been a big week for inflation numbers. We got two major reports from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, on consumer prices and producer prices. We also got reports on consumer inflation expectations and on business inflation expectations — which I’ve become increasingly interested in. Across these, the news ranged from decent to great. We still don’t know for sure if we’ll manage to get inflation under control without a recession, but the odds are looking better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Ukraine’s counteroffensive presses on.
content: Ukraine’s counteroffensive against Russia is making gains, albeit at a high cost, Ukrainian and American officials said. But after initially retaking some small settlements and villages, Ukraine’s advances in the Donetsk and Zaporizhzhia regions are better measured in yards than miles, according to independent analysts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Pickert
title: Is a Revolution in Cancer Treatment Within Reach?
description: New treatments are changing once deadly forms of the disease into manageable long-term illnesses. But not all patients are benefiting.
content: Carol MacKenzie had just finished playing a round of golf when she noticed some swelling and pain in her neck. It was 2014, and 18 years had passed since Ms. MacKenzie finished treatment for breast cancer. But it had returned. This time the cancer was growing inside several lymph nodes around her neck, plunging her back into treatment long after she thought that was all behind her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb and Tania Ganguli
title: Ja Morant’s Gun Videos Clash With N.B.A.’s Gun Safety Advocacy
description: Morant, the Memphis Grizzlies star, was suspended for 25 games for recklessly waving a gun in a video shared on social media in May. It was the second time he had done so.
content: As the United States grapples with the very American problem of rampant gun violence, the issue of gun safety has touched the N.B.A. through one of its brightest young stars, Ja Morant of the Memphis Grizzlies, who was suspended for 25 games on Friday after recklessly waving a gun around in a social media video for a second time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Japan Changes Its Rape Laws to Require Consent
description: Japan’s previous laws on sexual assault did not mention permission and required that the crime include physical force. The new law also raises the age of consent to 16, from 13.
content: Japan changed its definition of rape and raised the age of consent to 16, from 13, on Friday, bringing the country’s sex crimes laws closer in line with those in the United States and Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: How to Use A.I. as a Shopping Assistant
description: Doing product research, making grocery lists and booking travel can be easier with tools like ChatGPT.
content: Hello! We’re back with another edition of On Tech: A.I., a pop-up newsletter that teaches you about artificial intelligence, how it works and how to use it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Taking a Late-in-Life Victory Lap, Thanks to His Novel’s ‘Lunatic Energy’
description: Plunket's 1983 novel, “My Search for Warren Harding,” was out of print for decades — but remained stealthily influential. Its reissue has catapulted him out of retirement.
content: Robert Plunket was living in a trailer park in Englewood, Fla., with his pug, Meatball, when an email interrupted his life of quiet retirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: He Ran Sudan’s Most Storied Hotel. Then He Had to Leave Everything Behind.
description: Thanasis Pagoulatos led the family business, Khartoum’s oldest inn, through decades of tumult. Sudan’s latest breakdown proved too much.
content: Even as fighter jets tore through Khartoum’s skies in April and the streets became a dystopian war zone amid a showdown between rival Sudanese fighters, Thanasis Pagoulatos had no intention of fleeing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: American Woman Dies at Neuschwanstein Castle After Push Down Cliff
description: The woman, 21, was visiting the popular German site with a friend when they met a man who persuaded them to take a little-used trail and then assaulted them both, the police said.
content: One American woman was killed and another was injured on Wednesday when a man pushed them down a cliff near Neuschwanstein Castle, the popular German tourist site at the foot of the Alps, the local police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: They Found a Tiny, Affordable Cabin on an Island. What Could Go Wrong?
description: The 825-square-foot house was theirs for $275,000. But there was one big drawback: Without a foundation, it was sinking into the earth.
content: For an escape in the San Juan Islands, a little more than two hours north of Seattle, Joe Herrin knew he wouldn’t need much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: My Father’s Day Plan
description: Start with crab toast, then let the possibilities — a juicy steak with duck fat potatoes, a meatball sub, some spiced oatmeal — take over.
content: Good morning. I had an exceptional lobster roll the other day, sitting with my family on the dock at Archie’s Lobster in Bass Harbor, Maine, as gulls soared on a southwest breeze. Some very good steamed clams, too. But it was the crab roll we ate there that’s been haunting my dreams, that makes me want to cook this weekend, to bring that flavor back into my life: sweet and saline meat, ever so lightly dressed, on a warm, buttered bun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Evidence in Trump Documents Case Hints at ‘Ongoing Investigations,’ Filing Says
description: Court papers from federal prosecutors in the case against Donald Trump suggested that other criminal cases could potentially emerge from the inquiry.
content: The federal prosecutors overseeing the classified documents case against former President Donald J. Trump said in court papers on Friday that the evidence they are poised to give the defense as part of the normal process of discovery contained information about “ongoing investigations” that could “identify uncharged individuals.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Stan Lee’ Review: For the Cameo King, a Struggle to Hold the Spotlight
description: Disappointingly, this creation story of Lee gives way to the characters he helped create.
content: Onscreen, Stan Lee — the public face of Marvel Comics and the subject, mostly, of David Gelb’s chipper documentary of the same name — had cameos as an astronaut, a general, a strip club M.C., a beauty pageant judge, a letter carrier, an intergalactic barber, a psych ward resident, a hot dog vendor and many hapless pedestrians. He was never the superhero. But Lee believed that his success was because his superheroes’ neuroses, flaws and ego trips made each one a little bit like him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Sadiba Hasan
title: What Greta Lee, Lizzy Caplan and Spike Lee Wore to Party This Week
description: At an Apollo Theater benefit and a Tribeca Film Festival party, attendees showed off multicolored sequins and pastel tulle.
content: On Monday night, luminaries of music and film, dressed in ruffles, sequins and tulle, gathered in Harlem at the Apollo Theater and in SoHo for a Tribeca Film Festival dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: BAM Plans a Smaller Next Wave Festival
description: The lineup for the artistic director’s final season will feature an interactive food theater performance and several dance programs.
content: An intimate dinner-party performance, a fire-and-brimstone immersive show and a slew of dance performances are on tap for the coming Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the performing arts center announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Jeffrey Wright Give a Rousing Speech in ‘Asteroid City’
description: Wes Anderson narrates a scene from his film.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Testosterone Therapy Does Not Raise Heart Risk in a Group of Men
description: New results from a large study are reassuring, but questions remain about long-term safety, and about use by men without medical conditions.
content: The largest study ever done to evaluate the safety of hormone replacement for men has reassuring news for a limited group of patients whose bodies don’t produce enough testosterone, finding that the hormone does not increase heart attacks, strokes and cardiac deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: A Flood, a Boxcutter and a Son’s Pursuit to Keep His Father’s Legacy
description: Nachume Miller’s bright, naturalistic paintings from his final years are on view in Manhattan. They’re intact only thanks to his son, Danny Miller.
content: When a pipe burst in the warehouse that contained the artworks of the painter Nachume Miller, flooding the storage facility with pools of water and destroying hundreds of drawings and paintings, it was a wake-up call for Miller’s son, Danny Miller. He jolted into action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Sophia Lanman and Rowan Niemisto
title: Reddit Revolts, MrBeast’s YouTube Empire and Peak Trust and Safety?
description: Social platforms are entering a strange and uncertain future.
content: Moderators on Reddit have shut down their forums in protest of a new policy that charges users for access to the site’s API. The revolt has put Kevin in child care-wisdom-withdrawal (RIP r/daddit) — and left many other users without their favorite subreddits. But does the incident say something more about the future of the internet?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: 5 Things to Know About Francis Suarez
description: Mr. Suarez, who is entering the Republican presidential race, is a cryptocurrency enthusiast who holds a largely ceremonial job as mayor of Miami.
content: Francis X. Suarez, the two-term mayor of Miami who formally announced his entry into the 2024 presidential race on Thursday, is presenting himself as a fresh face for the Republican Party: a 45-year-old in a field led by a septuagenarian, and a Cuban American in a party whose elected officials are overwhelmingly white.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. National Debt Tops $32 Trillion for First Time
description: The milestone follows a recent congressional showdown over lifting the debt ceiling. Another spending fight looms this year.
content: The gross national debt exceeded $32 trillion for the first time on Friday, underscoring the country’s unsettling fiscal trajectory as Washington gears up for another fight over government spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: This C.S. Lewis Novel Helps Explain the Weirdness of 2023
description: A work of supernatural science fiction for an age of magic and paranoia.
content: Recently I reread C.S. Lewis’s 1945 novel, “That Hideous Strength,” the last book in his Space Trilogy, and since I wrote about aliens last weekend it seems like a good week to talk a little bit about the novel’s contemporary relevance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Vivienne Walt
title: Saudi Arabia Arrives in Paris, Shopping for Deals
description: A contingent from the kingdom, including its powerful crown prince, are in the French capital looking to spend big on investments.
content: Just days after the PGA-LIV Golf merger was announced, a contingent of Saudi Arabian investors and power brokers, including the crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, has converged on France this week looking for more deals with potentially trillions to spend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: UPS Workers Authorize Teamsters Union to Call Strike
description: A walkout is possible after the contract for more than 325,000 workers expires this summer. Negotiations began in April but have yet to resolve pay.
content: United Parcel Service workers have authorized their union, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, to call a strike as soon as Aug. 1, after the current contract expires, the Teamsters announced Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: In Trump Prosecution, Special Counsel Seeks to Avoid Distracting Fights
description: Jack Smith has taken an iron-fist-in-a-kid-glove approach, sidestepping secondary issues that could divert attention from the weight of the evidence he has assembled in his case against the former president.
content: Jonathan Goodman, the magistrate judge assigned to handle Donald J. Trump’s arraignment, did something of a double take during the proceeding on Tuesday, when the Justice Department offered the former president a bond deal that was not merely lenient but imposed virtually no restrictions on him at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: How Africa Can Help the World
description: We often ask whether the 54 countries on the continent can leapfrog fossil fuels and go straight to renewable energy. That may be the wrong question.
content: Next week in Paris, a critical diplomatic meeting begins on how to enable low-income, climate-vulnerable countries to grow their economies while reducing their dependence on fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Republicans Attack Blinken for China Trip, Threatening Subpoena
description: Republicans rebuked the secretary of state for visiting China for diplomatic talks as they advocate a hard-line, military-first approach to Beijing.
content: Leading congressional Republicans excoriated Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Friday for traveling to China this weekend, accusing him of undermining national security by attempting to normalize diplomatic relations with Beijing as they press for a more hard-line approach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: A Relationship ‘Worth Fighting For’ Despite Some Bumps Along the Way
description: Fay Leshner and Andrew Ousley have survived some ups and downs over the years. The pandemic helped them appreciate the life they built.
content: Andrew Douglas Ousley and Fay Eva Leshner met through mutual friends on Aug. 9, 2014 while having cocktails at the now-closed Portuguese restaurant Pão! in SoHo. They bonded instantly, as creative New Yorkers often do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: The N.C.A.A. Wants More Money From TV. Maxing That Out Could Prove Tricky.
description: Many college sports championships, including the marquee women’s basketball tournament, have been sold as a bundle. The prospect of selling separately raises questions for dozens of sports.
content: For more than 20 years, fans of college sports like softball, baseball, women’s basketball and more than two dozen others have known just where to find N.C.A.A. championships — on ESPN’s spectrum of channels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucinda Holt, Eduardo Medina, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Mike Ives
title: In Texas Town Pummeled By Tornado, Residents Pick Through Rubble
description: A tornado destroyed a trailer park as it battered the Texas Panhandle city of Perryton, where three people died. Another person was killed in Florida. A fifth person died in Mississippi.
content: Residents of Perryton, Texas, were sifting through piles of splintered plywood and mangled mobile homes on Friday in search of any belongings they could salvage — an Iron Man action figure, a spatula wedged in wet dirt, clothes caught on barbed wire — after a deadly tornado destroyed much of its downtown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Krysten Chambrot
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Arizona Man Is Freed After 28 Years on Death Row
description: A judge overturned Barry Jones’s conviction on charges that he sexually assaulted and murdered his girlfriend’s 4-year-old daughter in 1994.
content: Wearing a T-shirt that read “Free Bird,” an Arizona man who spent nearly 28 years on death row was freed on Thursday after a judge overturned his conviction on charges that he had sexually assaulted and murdered his girlfriend’s 4-year-old daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Will Reid, Mary Wilson, Stella Tan, Mooj Zadie, Paige Cowett, Lexie Diao, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: The Kids Take the Climate Change Fight to Court
description: A group of young environmentalists argue that Montana’s embrace of fossil fuels is robbing them of their future.
content: This week, a historic case has landed in a Montana courtroom. A group of young environmentalists is suing the state, arguing that its embrace of fossil fuels is destroying pristine environments, upending cultural traditions and robbing young residents of a healthy future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Mixed Business at an Anxious Art Basel
description: Dealers were hoping to send positive signals in the face of a possible downturn, but the Swiss fair’s bustle didn’t always translate into sales.
content: After an underwhelming series of auctions in New York in May, dealers exhibiting at this year’s Art Basel fair in Switzerland — which opened to V.I.P.s on Tuesday and welcomes the general public from Friday onward — hoped to quell concerns about a dip in the art market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why Has California Been So Cloudy Lately?
description: “June Gloom” has felt extra gloomy this year.
content: “June Gloom” has long been part of the California lexicon, an almost-rhyming reminder that a few weeks of overcast skies typically precede a sunny, scalding summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart
title: Famed Wine Store Sherry-Lehmann Faces Criminal Investigation
description: A federal grand jury is scheduled to hear evidence about Sherry-Lehmann, whose customers and former employees have complained about missing wine.
content: The Justice Department has convened a federal grand jury as part of a criminal investigation into Sherry-Lehmann Wine & Spirits, the venerable New York City wine merchant, according to former employees who have been contacted by the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: At the U.S. Open, Wyndham Clark Is Confident, and It Shows
description: Bold play in honor of his mother, who died nearly 10 years ago, had Clark flirting with the top of the leaderboard for part of his second round on Friday.
content: When Wyndham Clark was a kid, his mother, Lise, would tuck short written notes in his knapsack, little missives meant to lift his spirits or motivate him during the day. Clark tried to hide the notes from classmates because they became a source of teasing, especially when he was younger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: They Were Not Looking For Anything Serious. Surprise!
description: Hugh Baran and Jacob Rozenberg started out as friends with benefits, but eventually wanted to repair the world and host Shabbat together.
content: As Hugh Stephen Baran headed home in April 2015 to the Upper East Side of Manhattan after a Passover Seder with some high school friends in Englewood, N.J., Jacob Ellis Kaplan Rozenberg messaged him on Grindr, a dating app for gay men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Top Grammy Categories Are Returning to 8 Nominees, From 10
description: The event is also moving two competitions into its “general” field, adding three awards, and setting a new threshold for collaborators in album of the year.
content: Two years ago, the Grammy Awards abruptly increased the number of nominees permitted in its top categories, going to 10 slots on the ballot, from eight. Now, it is going back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: What Has Happened in Minneapolis Since George Floyd Was Murdered
description: A 2022 state review found that racial discrimination was endemic in the Police Department.
content: A cellphone video taken by a teenage bystander showing a white police officer, Derek Chauvin, pressing his knee on the neck of a 46-year-old Black man, George Floyd, on a Minneapolis street corner on May 25, 2020, led to the largest social-justice protest movement in the United States in a half-century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: A Big Family Just Got a Little Bigger
description: Just months after they began dating in 2018, Jonathan Gold introduced Diana Ming, an only child of Chinese immigrants, to his large extended family. She said she felt immediately embraced.
content: Neither Diana Ming nor Jonathan Barrett Gold seemed to want their first date to ever end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim  Wheeler and Dan Bilefsky
title: 10 Minutes From Their Destination, a Crash Took Their Lives
description: A road trip to a casino turned deadly yesterday for 15 people aboard a bus in Manitoba, Canada, that collided with a semitrailer truck.
content: It was supposed to be a fun escape: a group of elderly people from a sleepy town in Manitoba traveling by bus to a casino where they could play the slot machines and perhaps enjoy the Oasis restaurant’s bison pasta. Instead, police said, at least 15 people were killed and 10 injured when a semitrailer truck slammed into the bus on a rural stretch of highway about 10 minutes from their destination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Wertheim
title: The Tale the West Tells Itself About Ukraine
description: Ukraine’s best path to peace is to be well armed and supported outside NATO — not to join it.
content: Sometimes the stories we tell to win the war help us lose the peace. After the 9/11 attacks, the United States decided the Taliban government in Afghanistan was as culpable as the Qaeda terrorists who struck America. It then spent 20 years trying to keep the Taliban entirely out of power, only to cede the whole country to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: ‘It Could Have Been So Much Worse’: Mountain Collapse Narrowly Misses Swiss Village
description: Fifty million cubic feet of rock came to rest just shy of Brienz and its schoolhouse.
content: After decades of threatening to tear off and plummet down the slope, obliterating the homes below, the mountainside near the village of Brienz, in central Switzerland, finally collapsed. Geologists had predicted in May that the long-feared landslide was imminent, and the authorities evacuated the village’s roughly 85 residents. On Friday, the experts were proved right: A portion of the mountain gave way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Daniel Ellsberg, Who Leaked the Pentagon Papers, Is Dead at 92
description: Deeply disturbed by the accounting of American deceit in Vietnam, he approached The New York Times. The disclosures that followed rocked the nation.
content: Daniel Ellsberg, a military analyst who after experiencing a sobbing antiwar epiphany on a bathroom floor made the momentous decision in 1971 to disclose a secret history of American lies and deceit in Vietnam, what came to be known as the Pentagon Papers, died on Friday at his home in Kensington, Calif., in the Bay Area. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Read the full Justice Department report.
description: The report, released Friday, is the result of a multiyear investigation into the Minneapolis Police Department following the death of George Floyd in 2020.
content: A Justice Department report, released on Friday, detailed systemic issues within the Minneapolis Police Department that it said led to the death of George Floyd, a 46-year-old Black man, in police custody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Meshell Ndegeocello’s Magnificent Mix, and 9 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Peggy Gou, Killer Mike, Sparklehorse and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Luciano Spalletti and the Power of Walking Away
description: The Napoli coach led his team to a long-delayed title and then left because the job was done. That is worth celebrating.
content: Luciano Spalletti’s farm sits high on a ridge outside Montaione, a peaceful, strikingly pretty Italian village set on a hilltop an hour or so southwest of Florence. It is picture-perfect Tuscany: cobbled piazzas lined with cafes; echoing, cobbled streets; a panorama of deep blue skies and verdant olive groves on rolling hills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: An Experimental Master Gets His Due Onstage in New York
description: Anthony Braxton’s music is difficult to program even among forward-thinking institutions. Leave it to the scrappy companies to get the work done.
content: Anthony Braxton’s music is inherently theatrical. It’s also serious, and hilariously entertaining.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Rickie Fowler Reserves His Flash for the U.S. Open’s First Round
description: Fowler no longer wears blinding colors and his shaggy hair is long gone. But after years of struggle at major tournaments, the popular golfer quietly made U.S. Open history on Thursday.
content: No golf fans followed Rickie Fowler on Thursday dressed the same as he was. That used to be a thing in 2010 when Fowler, then 22, rode his relaxed dirt-biking roots and a boy band vibe complete with a top-to-toe orange outfit and a flat-brim hat to enormous popularity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Cyclist Dies After Mountain Crash in Tour de Suisse
description: Gino Mäder of Switzerland and another rider tumbled into a ravine during the fourth stage on Thursday. Mäder, 26, died Friday morning.
content: A Swiss bicycle racer who crashed on a fast descent during the Tour de Suisse died on Friday, one day after he and another competitor tumbled into a ravine in the Swiss Alps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany’s security strategy aims to set priorities after Russia’s invasion, but offers few hard commitments.
description: Haunted by its responsibility for World War II and Nazi tyranny, Germany embraced the pursuit of peace with the fervor of a convert. But on Wednesday, its government took an important step toward shedding that legacy as war once again transforms the European continent.
content: Haunted by its responsibility for World War II and Nazi tyranny, Germany embraced the pursuit of peace with the fervor of a convert. But on Wednesday, its government took an important step toward shedding that legacy as war once again transforms the European continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Freda Kreier
title: The Sad Story Behind a Fossil’s ‘Grin’
description: Rhynchosaurs were dominant reptiles on Earth as dinosaurs emerged, but an anatomical quirk may have contributed to a difficult old age and their eventual extinction.
content: Before the dawn of the dinosaurs, the world belonged to reptiles called rhynchosaurs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 16, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, June 16, 2023.
content: A picture caption with an article on Thursday about American companies that are paying for enriched uranium from Russia misstated the status of an enriched uranium plant in Ohio. The plant is U.S.-owned, not European-owned, and is currently idle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: A Star of Kenji López-Alt’s Childhood Breakfasts Shows Its Versatility
description: Briny tarako and spicy mentaiko, easily found at Korean and Japanese markets, adds saltiness and umami to potatoes, pasta and cream cheese.
content: I grew up in apartment 10J of a high rise in Morningside Heights, in Manhattan. My maternal grandparents — both Japanese immigrants — lived one floor below us, in 9J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Alexandra Berzon
title: The Business of Being Chris Christie
description: Mr. Christie left the governor’s office in New Jersey and set out to, as he put it, “make money.” He successfully traded on his political profile — and on his ties to the man he now wants to defeat.
content: As his second term as governor of New Jersey drew to a close in 2017, Chris Christie was characteristically blunt about his plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Glenn Thrush, Mitch Smith and Dan Simmons
title: Minneapolis Police Used Illegal, Abusive Practices for Years, Justice Dept. Finds
description: The city said it would try to negotiate a court-enforced consent decree with the federal government that would require an overhaul of its police force.
content: The Justice Department said on Friday that the Minneapolis police routinely discriminated against Black and Native American people, used deadly force without justification and trampled the First Amendment rights of protesters and journalists — damning findings that grew out of a multiyear investigation and may lead to a court-enforced overhaul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Endeavour’ Review: Farewell to the Morse Cinematic Universe
description: After three shows, 26 seasons and 36 years, one of TV’s most devoted fan bases will have to say goodbye to the world of its testy Oxford detective.
content: In a week that will see the returns of “And Just Like That …” and “The Bear” and the arrival of a new Marvel series, giving space to a creaky British mystery as it tiptoes into its ninth and final season might seem like an odd choice. But it’s just self preservation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
title: Southern Baptists’ Fight Over Female Leaders Shows Power of Insurgent Right
description: Moves this week to oust women from church leadership in the nation’s largest Protestant denomination offer an early look into the psyche of evangelical America ahead of 2024.
content: Two summers ago, an insurgent group of ultraconservative Southern Baptists branded themselves as pirates, vowing to “take the ship” of the nation’s largest Protestant denomination and steer it farther to the right on issues like sexuality and race.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wes Anderson’s Best Needle Drops
description: Hear songs that memorably accompanied scenes in “Rushmore,” “The Royal Tenenbaums” and more.
content: One day when I was 14, I stayed home sick from school and watched a weird little movie called “Rushmore” on Comedy Central. When it was over, I thought to myself, “Oh, so that’s what a director does.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Judge Mostly Blocks Indiana Ban on Transition Care for Minors
description: Transgender youth in the state will be able to access hormone treatments and puberty blockers while a lawsuit progresses.
content: A federal judge in Indiana largely blocked that state’s ban on transition medical care for youth from taking effect on July 1, the latest in a series of courtroom wins for transgender-rights advocates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: L.A.’s Center Theater Group Lays Off Staff and Halts Work on One Stage
description: With box office revenues, subscriptions and donations all down since the pandemic, the theater said it would pause production on one of its three stages, the Mark Taper Forum.
content: In the face of what is described as a “crisis unlike any other in our 56-year history,” the Center Theater Group, a flagship of the Los Angeles theater world, announced a series of sharp cutbacks Thursday to deal with drops in revenue and attendance and said that it would suspend productions at one of its three stages, the Mark Taper Forum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: How ‘Transformers: Rise of the Beasts’ Throws a ’90s Hip-Hop Party
description: The director and production designer of the latest installment in the robot action franchise discuss recreating the sights and sounds of 1990s Brooklyn culture.
content: In previous “Transformers” movies, fans have seen their beloved robots Optimus Prime, Bumblebee and Arcee battle their way out of plenty a dilemma. But have they ever seen an Autobot kick butt to the rhymes of LL Cool J? That’s the energy of “Transformers: Rise of the Beasts” (in theaters), with its director Steven Caple Jr. giving the franchise an inclusive spin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: chastise
description: This word has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word chastise has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 21 in “Review: Pulling Back the Curtain on ‘The Magic Flute’ at the Met” by Oussama Zahr:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Reading Spy Fiction, and About Those Who Wrote It
description: Extracurricular reading this week turned out to be very spy-focused, with appearances by John le Carré and Robert Gottlieb.
content: A friend asked me recently how I managed to read all the things I recommend in my Friday newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Overdraft Fees Are Dwindling, Study Finds
description: But the share of people paying the fees remains unchanged, and they’re often among the most financial vulnerable.
content: Are the days of overdraft fees almost over?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Johanna Lemola
title: Conservatives Poised to Lead Finland in Coalition with Hard Right
description: When the party of the country’s political rock star, former Prime Minister Sanna Marin, lost in April, a center-right party’s power rose.
content: Finland’s main conservative party announced a new coalition government on Friday after weeks of negotiations, in a deal that moves the country firmly to the right and follows a pattern of similar political shifts elsewhere in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Danielson
title: Alone Together: 4 Picture Books That Pair Solitude With Friendship
description: “Sometimes it’s nice to be alone. Just you, reading your book. … But what if a friend stops by?”
content: Picture books can do anything. Today they take on subjects that were largely ignored during my childhood, such as socioemotional awareness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Amazon’s Freevee Embraces the Judy-Verse
description: The free, ad-supported streaming service is quadrupling down on Judge Judith Sheindlin. And she’s bringing her “nepo babies” along.
content: In 2021, Judge Judith Sheindlin, the razor-tongued court show star, decamped from the dying medium of daytime broadcast syndication and joined Amazon for a streaming-era experiment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Jon Moss
title: Jury Convicts Man in Killing of 11 in Pittsburgh Synagogue
description: Jurors will next hear arguments about whether the defendant, Robert Bowers, should be sentenced to death.
content: The gunman who killed 11 worshipers in a Pittsburgh synagogue in October 2018 was found guilty on Friday of dozens of federal hate crimes and civil rights offenses, closing the first stage of a trial that may ultimately end in a death sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Why Do So Few Democrats Want Biden to Run in 2024?
description: Obama’s former speechwriter Jon Favreau talks age, approval ratings and other obstacles the president will face in 2024.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb and Tania Ganguli
title: Michael Jordan to Sell Majority Stake in Charlotte Hornets
description: Jordan, the former star of the Chicago Bulls, purchased the team in 2010.
content: Michael Jordan, the owner of the Charlotte Hornets and one of the world’s most storied athletes, has agreed to sell his majority share in the N.B.A. team to a group led by Gabe Plotkin and Rick Schnall, two private equity investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Review: In London, a ‘Romeo and Juliet’ That Feels Startlingly New
description: Toheeb Jimoh, Emmy-nominated for “Ted Lasso,” takes on Romeo in a riveting production from the British director Rebecca Frecknall.
content: “Is love a tender thing?” Romeo asks early in the Shakespeare tragedy to which he and Juliet give their names. Not so much, according to the raw and riveting new production of “Romeo and Juliet” that opened Wednesday at the Almeida Theater here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael Corkery
title: Calling for New Gun Laws, Biden Says U.S. Children Are Suffering Like Soldiers in War
description: “If this Congress refuses to act, we need a new Congress,” President Biden said at a firearms safety summit in Connecticut.
content: President Biden made a forceful case on Friday for stronger gun laws, saying American children caught up in school shootings are suffering from the same trauma as soldiers in war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: David Balton and Jane Stewart take us for a ride on la strada. Molto bene!
content: ACROSTIC — This is another acrostic with a byline that’s new to Times puzzles, a collaboration between David Balton and Jane Stewart. It excerpts a 1991 book called “Neither Here Nor There,” a European travelogue by the journalist and prolific nonfiction author Bill Bryson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Two Former Tucker Carlson Producers Exit Fox News
description: The departures are the latest fallout since the network sidelined Mr. Carlson in April.
content: Two top producers for Tucker Carlson’s former show have left Fox News, in the latest fallout from the network’s benching of Mr. Carlson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: Why Egusi Is More Than Just a Great Soup
description: Incredibly popular across West Africa, the dish can vary from cook to cook and place to place, but, for Yewande Komolafe, it’s a quick link to the past.
content: Every cook has at least one hard-to-get ingredient that they know they can find almost anywhere they are, as long as they’re persistent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Putin rejects claims that Russia is isolated, projecting a rosy economic outlook.
description: President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday rejected suggestions that Russia had become isolated over its invasion of Ukraine, telling an audience in St. Petersburg that the Russian economy was resilient and that Moscow’s ties with other nations had grown.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday rejected suggestions that Russia had become isolated over its invasion of Ukraine, telling an audience in St. Petersburg that the Russian economy was resilient and that Moscow’s ties with other nations had grown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: What to Know About Ezra Miller and ‘The Flash’
description: The 30-year-old star of the much-delayed DC film was in hot water amid a spate of legal troubles. Here’s where those cases stand.
content: “The Flash,” the much-delayed Warner Bros. superhero film about a speedster who travels back in time to try to prevent his mother’s murder, is finally, actually, for real hitting theaters on Friday. Based on the DC Comics character, the new blockbuster has survived three director changes and, most recently, the legal troubles of its star superhero, Ezra Miller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Tunisians Mourn a Hard-Fought Freedom Rapidly Slipping Away
description: When reflecting on their Arab Spring revolution, Tunisians often say that freedom of expression was the only concrete achievement. As the country slides back toward autocracy, that, too, is being quickly eroded.
content: Mosaïque FM, Tunisia’s most popular radio station, comes to life each morning around 5:30 a.m. with the martial strains of the national anthem. Next comes a voice crooning a verse from the Quran, then music and news, followed by the political show “Watch What They Say,” which has chronicled the floundering of the country’s young democracy and its recent U-turn toward autocracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: A Stage Musical About Belfast’s Punk Oasis
description: ‘Good Vibrations’ at the Irish Arts Center takes a snapshot of life in Northern Ireland during the Troubles through its music scene.
content: Of all the streets to open a record store, one nicknamed Bomb Alley might not have been optimal. Then again this was Belfast in 1977, when the nationalistic, sectarian violence known as the Troubles made retail perilous pretty much everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: From estranged parents making amends, to harsh battles for homelands, this month’s action picks feature appeals to families.
content: There’s a twist in the Malaysian director Adrian Teh’s “The Assistant” that’s so outlandish you can’t help but love the sheer force of its swing. The timid Zafik (Iedil Dzuhrie Alaudin) has recently been released from prison. Ten years prior, a mystery man planted cocaine in his car. Two years after that, the same person, presumably, killed his wife and son. Now, he wants answers. For help, he first turns to his best friend, Dato Sam Lee (Henley Hii), a wealthy frontman for a local gangster. Then he links up with his wife’s cousin, Feroz (Hairul Azreen), who also wants to find the culprit behind the murders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Choose Wisely, Choose Often: Ranked-Choice Voting Returns to New York
description: The new voting system was used in the mayor’s race in 2021. It is back this month for the primary races for the City Council.
content: The last time New Yorkers went to the polls, they had to contemplate a governor’s race and a slew of congressional races in the critical 2022 midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Pina Bausch’s Dance Company Announces Steps Toward a New Era
description: Tanztheater Wuppertal unveiled its first season under Boris Charmatz, as well as plans for a new, multipurpose center.
content: What is the identity of the Tanztheater Wuppertal without Pina Bausch, who transformed this regional German troupe into a world-famous ensemble associated with her grand-scale mix of absurdist humor, mordant darkness and visceral movement?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Coast Guard Ends Post-9/11 Antiterrorism Patrols at Guantánamo Bay
description: Special teams were sent to the U.S. outpost in Cuba after the Sept. 11 attacks. The Coast Guard said a Navy sea patrol assumed their duties.
content: The U.S. Coast Guard has ended its antiterrorism patrols of the waters around Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, shutting down a special security operation that was rushed to the remote outpost after the Sept. 11 attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Prince Harry and Meghan to Part Ways With Spotify
description: The couple’s production company and the streaming service announced an end to their relationship, less than a year after Meghan’s podcast debuted on the platform.
content: Spotify and Archewell Audio, the production company started by Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, have ended their partnership less than a year after her podcast, “Archetypes,” debuted on the platform, the companies announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s Going On With Reddit?
description: Thousands of subreddits have gone dark in protest.
content: If you tried to find information on Reddit over the last week, you might have had a hard time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: At an ‘Apocalyptic Wedding’, Love (and Smoke) Was in the Air
description: Deanna Arthur and Grey Cohen were wed at City Hall in New York as the city’s polluted air broke historical records and an orange haze blanketed the smoke-filled sky.
content: On June 7, the skies were hazy and gray as smoke and ash billowed into New York from wildfires in eastern Canada. Despite the ‘end days are nigh’ gloom of the city, Deanna Marie Arthur and Grey Noah Cohen were strutting through the downtown streets in formal wedding attire — Ms. Arthur in an off-the-shoulder Jenny Yu gown and Mx. Cohen, who uses they/them pronouns and a gender-neutral courtesy title, in a gray tuxedo — and recording the rapidly darkening day with a hand-held video camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: U.S. Soccer Team Thrashes Mexico in Grudge Match in Las Vegas
description: Two goals from Christian Pulisic led the United States over Mexico in a nasty Nations League semifinal that was ended early because of homophobic chanting.
content: In the first significant match for either team since the World Cup, the United States soccer team dominated a reeling Mexico, 3-0, in the semifinals of a regional championship tournament on Thursday night in Las Vegas. The victory, on the strength of two goals from the American star Christian Pulisic and another from forward Ricardo Pepi, sent the United States to the final of the tournament, the Concacaf Nations League. The Americans won the inaugural edition of the tournament in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A New Front in Reparations and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
description: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rose
title: Making Art Out of Bombshells and Memories in Vietnam
description: Tuan Andrew Nguyen’s videos and sculptures uncover haunting artifacts and stories from the Vietnam War. They’re coming soon to the New Museum.
content: Not quite 20 minutes into “The Unburied Sounds of a Troubled Horizon,” a film by the artist Tuan Andrew Nguyen, the camera settles on a distinctive-looking monument at the far end of a wooden footbridge. We’re in Quang Tri province, central Vietnam. The bridge spans the Ben Hai River, which for 21 years, from the French debacle at Dien Bien Phu in 1954 to the fall of Saigon in 1975, was the demarcation line between North and South Vietnam. A couple of miles in either direction was the so-called Demilitarized Zone, a “buffer” that became one of the most-bombed places on the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Twitch Star Signs $100 Million Deal With Rival Platform
description: The deal signed by Félix Lengyel, known as xQc, matches traditional athletes’ contracts, and is another sign of Twitch’s tense relationship with its top streamers.
content: One of Twitch’s most popular streamers said on Friday that he was joining a rival streaming platform, Kick, in a significant blow to the Amazon-owned site and a sign of its increasingly strained relationship with content creators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: As Blinken Heads to China, a Wall of Suspicion Awaits Him
description: Even as Beijing prepares for a visit by the secretary of state, China’s leader has made clear his expectations of more hostile superpower competition.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken makes his long-delayed visit to China beginning Sunday in the hope of slowing the downward spiral of relations between Beijing and Washington. But China’s increasingly assertive, at times outright hostile, stance suggests that the visit will be as much about confrontation as détente.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Putin Asserts Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Has ‘No Chance’ at Economic Forum
description: By claiming to be in control at a pivotal moment, critics say, he can no longer pass any military failures off on others.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia wrapped up what was for him an extraordinary and sometimes rambling week of upbeat commentary on the Ukraine war by asserting on Friday that Russia was so assured of prevailing against the Ukrainian counteroffensive that he had ruled out using nuclear weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson, Out of Parliament, Is a Columnist Again
description: Britain’s former prime minister, who quit as a lawmaker in the face of a possible suspension for misleading statements about pandemic gatherings, will write for The Daily Mail, a tabloid.
content: Boris Johnson’s image was splashed across the front pages of London newspapers on Friday, a day after a parliamentary committee condemned him for misleading lawmakers about parties during the coronavirus pandemic. But it was conspicuously absent from The Daily Mail, the biggest and most influential British tabloid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Richard Severo, Times Reporter in Internal Clash Over Book, Dies at 90
description: He challenged a company’s prerogative to transfer an employee and a news organization’s ability to assert publishing rights when a reporter’s articles are used for a book.
content: Richard Severo, a prizewinning reporter for The New York Times whose challenge to what he considered a punitive transfer by the newspaper’s management became a cause célèbre among journalists in the 1980s, died on June 12 at his home in Balmville, N.Y., in the Hudson Valley. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pope Francis Leaves Rome Hospital and Returns to Vatican After Surgery
description: Doctors have advised the 86-year-old pontiff to take it easy after an operation to deal with a hernia that caused painful intestinal blockages.
content: Pope Francis returned to the Vatican on Friday after he was released from a Rome hospital following abdominal surgery for a hernia, the third time in two years that the 86-year-old pontiff has been hospitalized.

title: A Bull or a Bear Market? It Doesn’t Matter.

content: The headlines and market analyses of the last few weeks, saying that stocks are in a bull market, may be a comfort even if they are potentially misleading.

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Hiding Behind the Hedges
description: In Los Angeles, the wealthy will pay a fortune to protect their private lives from prying eyes. At least leafy green walls are good for the environment.
content: The homes of Hollywood’s rich and famous have long been enclosed by walls of sky-high ficus, designed to shield their wealthy occupants from paparazzi and peeping Toms alike. Robert Frost may have thought good fences make good neighbors, but in Los Angeles, those fences are planted rather than built.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Love Letter: A New Life
description: How a son’s invitation to draw cartoons led to a sea change in a father’s life.
content: “My father was not much of a talker,” writes Brian Frazer. “My mother’s overbearing personality had forced him into a shell — getting more than a word or two out of him was rare.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: Review: ‘The Whitney Album’ Looks to Theater to Remake a Painful Past
description: Eschewing a conventional narrative, Jillian Walker’s soulful show seeks to heal deep wounds through ritual and celebratory singalongs.
content: In “The Whitney Album,” a heady and ritualistic new show that recently opened at Soho Rep, the playwright and actor Jillian Walker uses Whitney Houston as an object lesson: The pressures heaped on gifted and famous Black women, Walker suggests, are stifling, destructive and rooted in colonial subjugation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: A Better Way to Help Families
description: In an important shift in poverty policy, states are starting to provide lower-income families with something new: cash.
content: For the past three decades, federal aid for lower-income families has largely consisted of handing out coupons: housing vouchers for families that need housing; food stamps for families that need food; Medicaid cards for health care.

title: Carol Higgins Clark, Mystery Writer, Is Dead at 66
description: She had a modest career as an actress but was best known for following in the footsteps of her mother, the best-selling author Mary Higgins Clark.
content: Carol Higgins Clark, who as a young woman retyped manuscripts by her mother, the famed mystery writer Mary Higgins Clark, before going on to become a best-selling suspense novelist herself, died on Monday in Los Angeles. She was 66.

content: This week, the head of the United Nations atomic watchdog, Rafael Mariano Grossi, was so concerned about a new risk at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant that he flew to Ukraine and crossed the front line in the country’s war with Russia to see the situation for himself.

description: Three years ago, Steven Kraft disappeared. This week, Jamie and Nicholas Orsini were arrested and accused of carrying out an elaborate plot to kill him and dispose of his body.
content: Just before 4 p.m. on April 28, 2020, Steven Kraft did as he often did on Tuesday afternoons. He left his job at a deli in Marlboro, N.Y., and headed across the Hudson River to Beacon, where he picked up his two middle-school-aged children from his ex-wife’s house. He caught up with them over a fast-food dinner before returning them to their mother’s home around 7 p.m.

content: An alarm at the International Boxing Hall of Fame in Canastota, N.Y., blared at about 2 a.m. on a fall morning in 2015, prompting its director to drive to the building and learn that culprits had broken in and stolen six championship belts from the ’40s and ’50s.

description: The court split 3-3 on whether to revive a much stricter six-week limit, enacted in 2018, that was struck down before Roe v. Wade was overturned.
content: A legal attempt to ban abortion in Iowa after six weeks of pregnancy failed on Friday, after the State Supreme Court deadlocked over whether to vacate a lower court’s injunction and allow the ban to take effect. That means abortion will remain legal in Iowa through 20 weeks of pregnancy.

description: The holiday has long flourished in local spaces of Black life in America.
content: It’s been two years since Juneteenth became a federal holiday, one we can celebrate together as a nation. The signing of the Juneteenth National Independence Day Act into law in 2021 was an expression of real progress in the collective understanding of Black struggle that reinforced our national ideals of liberty and dignity. But I confess my ambivalence. I am worried about what official national recognition might do to what has always been a community-based holiday.
source.name: The New York Times
